Question: What factors affect the price of Guntur Chilli?
answer:
1. The first thing buyers look at is quality: pods that are bright red, uniform, with high pungency and low moisture always fetch a premium.  
2. Variety matters; popular export types such as 334, Teja (S-17) or Wonder Hot get higher rates than local or mixed lots.  
3. Grades are fixed in the Guntur market based on moisture, length, colour and amount of broken or damaged pods—better grades mean better price.  
4. Daily supply at the Guntur yard strongly affects the rate: when many lorry-loads arrive after harvest, prices dip; when arrivals are thin, rates rise.  
5. Overall production levels in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Karnataka change the price—drought, heavy rain, or pest attacks that cut yield usually push prices up.  
6. Export demand from China, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and the Gulf can suddenly raise prices; a slowdown or higher freight costs pull them down.  
7. Domestic festival and masala-industry demand (e.g., before Diwali or Ramzan) also creates temporary spikes.  
8. Cold-storage capacity influences the market: if farmers or traders can hold stock, they release slowly and keep prices firm; when stores are full, they rush sales and prices fall.  
9. Government moves—such as export incentives, pesticide residue alerts, or changes in minimum support for alternative crops—indirectly sway chilli prices.  
10. Finally, daily auction mood and information flow matter, so checking updated market arrivals and rates before deciding to sell can add several rupees per kilo to your income.

Question: What is the appropriate age for vaccination of cows?
answer:
1. No vaccine is needed at birth; just be sure the calf gets plenty of colostrum within the first 2 hours.  
2. Begin vaccinations when the calf is 3–4 months old, because by that age the protection from colostrum has fallen.  
3. Foot-and-Mouth Disease (FMD): first dose at 4 months, booster one month later, then repeat every 6 months (usually Feb–Mar and Sept–Oct).  
4. Haemorrhagic Septicaemia (HS): first dose at 4–6 months, then one shot every year just before the monsoon.  
5. Black Quarter (BQ): first dose at 6 months, then yearly along with the HS vaccine.  
6. Brucellosis (S-19 vaccine): give one dose to female calves only, between 4 and 8 months of age; no booster is needed later.  
7. Anthrax (only in areas where the disease occurs): first dose at 6 months, then yearly.  
8. Theileriosis vaccine (optional but useful in cross-bred animals): single dose at about 3–4 months of age.  
9. Keep all vaccines in an ice box while you travel, use a new sterile needle for every animal, and record the date on a wall chart.  
10. Follow this schedule and your cattle will be well protected, but always consult your local veterinarian if disease risk in your area changes.

Question: What cheyyali to prevent the mango tree from rotting and falling
answer:
1. Keep rain-water from standing near the base of the mango: make a shallow ring-basin 50-60 cm away from the trunk and dig a small drain so excess water flows out quickly.  
2. Mix 2–3 kg well-decomposed farmyard manure + 250 g neem-cake + 50 g Trichoderma viride powder in the topsoil around each tree every year; this encourages good microbes that suppress root-rot fungi.  
3. Once a year, scrape loose, cracked or blackened bark from the collar region, let it dry for a day, and paint the cleaned area with Bordeaux paste or 3 % copper oxychloride paste to stop stem-rot and gummosis.  
4. Remove and burn any dead or badly infected branches immediately so the disease cannot spread.  
5. Give balanced nutrition: per bearing tree apply about 50 kg FYM, 500 g N, 250 g P₂O₅ and 500 g K₂O in two splits (June–July and October) because weak, under-fed trees rot and fall more easily.  
6. Avoid mechanical injuries from ploughs or goats; if wounds occur, disinfect with 0.25 % copper oxychloride solution and then seal with Bordeaux paste.  
7. Never heap soil, mulch or fertilizers right against the trunk—keep at least a 15 cm gap so the collar stays dry and airy.  
8. For areas with strong winds, prune the tree after harvest to keep the canopy low and balanced, and tie young trees to a strong stake.  
9. In heavy rainfall zones, graft the scion on Phytophthora-tolerant rootstocks like Vellaikolumban if you plant new orchards.  
10. Inspect trees monthly; early detection of soft, dark, foul-smelling patches allows quick treatment and saves the whole tree.

Question: What are alternative crops to cowdung?
answer: Cow-dung is only one kind of organic manure; if you don’t have enough of it, you can feed the soil with other materials that give similar or even higher nutrient value. 1) Poultry litter (chicken droppings) contains about twice as much nitrogen as cow-dung, so apply 1.5–2 t/acre well-composted and mixed into the top 10 cm of soil. 2) Goat or sheep manure is rich in nitrogen and potassium; use 2–3 t/acre after 2–3 months of heaping and turning so it loses excess heat and salts. 3) Vermicompost made with earthworms from crop residues delivers balanced N-P-K and improves soil structure; 1 t/acre before sowing is enough for most field crops. 4) Press cakes of neem, groundnut or mustard left after oil extraction supply slow-release nitrogen and some phosphorus; broadcast 100–150 kg/acre and lightly incorporate. 5) Green-manure crops like dhaincha (Sesbania), sunhemp or cowpea can be sown, grown for 40–45 days, and ploughed under to add 4–6 t/acre of fresh biomass and about 40–60 kg N/ha. 6) Crop-residue compost (made from straw, husk, vegetable waste) put at 3–4 t/acre adds organic carbon and micronutrients. 7) If no organic source is available, balanced chemical fertilisers (for example 40 kg urea, 25 kg SSP, 15 kg MOP per acre for cereals) can supply nutrients, but always add at least some organic matter to keep soil lively. 8) Whatever option you choose, compost it well, keep moisture suitable, and avoid applying fresh, raw manure directly to standing crops to prevent burning and disease.

Question: What are the effects of marigold as a trap crop?
answer: Marigold works like a “sacrificial” plant that pulls pests away from your main crop and can even kill some soil-borne enemies. 1) Most Tagetes marigold varieties release chemicals (thiophenes) from their roots that suppress or kill root-knot nematodes, reducing galling on nearby vegetables like tomato, okra and brinjal. 2) The bright flowers attract sap-sucking insects and fruit borers (e.g., Helicoverpa), so fewer of these pests settle on your cash crop; you can then hand-pick or spray only the marigold rows. 3) Because pests concentrate on the marigold border, you use less pesticide overall and avoid spraying the food crop itself. 4) Marigold blooms also provide nectar and pollen that support ladybird beetles, hoverflies and parasitic wasps, increasing natural pest control. 5) The strong scent confuses some insects such as whiteflies and aphids, lowering their landing rate on neighbouring plants. 6) After 45–60 days you can cut and incorporate marigold biomass into the soil to add organic matter and keep suppressing nematodes. 7) Keep a 1:10 ratio—one row of marigold for every 10 rows of the main crop, or surround the field with a 45–60 cm wide strip—for best results.

Question: How do I prevent leaf blight in chili?
answer:
1. Use certified, disease-free seed or resistant/tolerant varieties such as Arka Lohit, Arka Abhir, or Suraj to keep the disease out of your field from the start.  
2. Before sowing, treat the seed with Thiram or Captan @ 3 g per kg seed (or Trichoderma harzianum @ 4 g per kg) to kill any blight fungus present.  
3. Raise seedlings on a raised, well-drained nursery bed, and drench the bed every 7–10 days with a 0.2 % solution of copper oxychloride to stop early infection.  
4. Transplant only healthy seedlings at a spacing of about 45 cm × 45 cm so that air moves freely and leaves dry quickly after rain or irrigation.  
5. Avoid overhead or late-evening irrigation; instead, use furrow or drip irrigation in the morning to stop water from splashing spores onto the leaves.  
6. Remove and burn the first infected leaves or plants you see, and keep the plot free of last season’s crop residues and weeds that harbour the blight pathogen.  
7. Apply 2–3 sprays of Mancozeb + Metalaxyl (e.g., Ridomil Gold) or copper oxychloride @ 2.5 g per litre at 10-day intervals when weather is warm and humid, starting as soon as you notice the first spots.  
8. Between chemical sprays, you can alternate with a biocontrol product containing Trichoderma or Bacillus subtilis to slow resistance build-up and lower costs.  
9. Always mix sticker/spreader (e.g., 1 ml liquid soap per litre) with sprays, and follow the pre-harvest interval (usually 5–7 days) to keep residues off the harvested chillies.

Question: Can the quantity of grain be increased in the absence of green fodder?
answer:
No.  Ruminant animals (cow, buffalo, goat) must have some bulky roughage in the ration to keep the rumen working; only increasing grain can cause acidosis, bloat and fall in milk-fat or even death.  
If fresh green fodder is not available, give 4–5 kg dry fodder (wheat/paddy straw, hay, stover) for every 1 kg concentrate mixture you offer.  
Enrich dry fodder by chopping it finely and, if possible, treating it with 4 kg urea + 40 kg water per 100 kg straw and covering it for 21 days; this raises its protein value.  
Silage made from maize, sorghum or Napier cut at the milk stage is another good substitute for greens and can be stored for 6–8 months.  
You can also supplement with tree leaves (subabul, babul, ber), hydroponic fodder, or 1–2 kg Azolla per animal per day.  
Do not exceed roughly 1 kg concentrate per 2–2.5 kg milk produced, and always mix 50–100 g mineral mixture plus a handful of common salt in the daily concentrate.  
Provide plenty of clean water.  
By keeping this balance of roughage and concentrate, the animals stay healthy and milk yield remains steady until fresh green fodder is again available.

Question: How do I to recognize milk fever in cows?
answer:
1. Milk fever (low blood calcium) usually strikes high-yield, older cows within 1–3 days after calving.  
2. First signs are loss of appetite, restlessness and fine muscle tremors in the shoulders, flanks or face.  
3. The ears, muzzle and legs feel unusually cold and the eyes look dull because body temperature drops.  
4. The cow stands with a stiff, shaky gait, often with her hind feet close together and her head turned toward her flank.  
5. Very soon she collapses onto her chest, then rolls onto her side and cannot rise.  
6. While down she keeps her head bent along her body, the rumen stops moving, little dung is passed and gas may build up, causing bloat.  
7. Breathing becomes slow, the heartbeat is weak and the cow may grunt with every breath.  
8. Without quick treatment (intravenous or subcutaneous calcium from a veterinarian) she can slip into a coma and die within 6–12 hours.  
9. Any freshly calved cow that is cold, shaky or unable to stand should be assumed to have milk fever and treated immediately.

Question: How do I to choose a suitable breed of cow?
answer:
1. First decide your main goal: high milk, draught power, or both—your purpose guides the breed.  
2. If you have good year-round fodder, shade, clean water and nearby veterinary services, choose proven crossbreds such as Holstein-Friesian × Gir or Jersey × Sahiwal, which can give 15–20 litres of milk per day.  
3. If your area is very hot, disease-prone or fodder is limited, hardy indigenous breeds like Gir, Sahiwal, Tharparkar or Red Sindhi are safer; they yield 8–12 litres but fall sick less and conceive easier.  
4. Check feed demand: a high-yielding crossbred needs about 25–30 kg green fodder, 4–5 kg concentrate and plenty of water daily, while indigenous cows manage with roughly two-thirds of that.  
5. Examine the individual animal—she should have a large, well-attached udder, straight teeth, bright eyes, strong legs and no nasal discharge or overgrown hooves.  
6. Ask to see milk-yield or lactation records; if none exist, watch her being milked and test milk yield yourself.  
7. Select cows that calve every 12–14 months; long calving intervals mean hidden fertility problems.  
8. Make sure vaccinations (FMD, HS, Brucellosis) and deworming are up to date, and quarantine the new cow for 2 weeks before mixing with your herd.  
9. Always buy from a reliable government farm, certified breeder or a farmer you trust, and insist on a bill of sale and health card.  
10. Finally, match the breed to your resources rather than only to headline milk numbers—healthy, manageable cows give better profit than fragile high-producers.

Question: What are some regenerative farming strategies I can try?
answer:
1. Keep living roots in the soil year-round by sowing short-duration cover crops such as cowpea, sunhemp, or dhaincha after harvest; they add organic matter and fix nitrogen for the next crop.  
2. Rotate crops so that cereals (e.g., maize, sorghum) are always followed by legumes (e.g., pigeon-pea, chickpea); this breaks pest cycles, improves soil fertility, and spreads your risk.  
3. Apply well-decomposed farmyard manure or vermicompost at 2–5 t/acre every season instead of relying only on chemical fertilisers; it feeds soil microbes and improves moisture-holding capacity.  
4. Leave crop residues as mulch or add rice straw/sugar-cane trash on the soil surface rather than burning; a 5 cm mulch layer reduces evaporation by up to 30 % and suppresses weeds.  
5. Minimise deep ploughing—use shallow tillage or a roto-weeder to disturb only the top 5–7 cm; this preserves earthworms and prevents soil erosion.  
6. Incorporate green manures like sunhemp at 40–50 kg seed/acre, ploughed in at 45 days, to release 40–60 kg of nitrogen and increase soil carbon.  
7. Practise Integrated Pest Management: install pheromone traps, release Trichogramma cards, and spray neem seed kernel extract (5 %) before using synthetic pesticides.  
8. Plant border strips or intercrops of marigold, sesame, or coriander around the main crop to attract beneficial insects and diversify farm income.  
9. If you have space, add nitrogen-fixing trees such as Gliricidia or Subabul on field boundaries; regular lopping provides fodder and leaf mulch without shading the crop.

Question: What to do if my cows are weak?
answer:
1. First, look at what the animals eat: give each adult cow 25-30 kg good green fodder (like napier, maize or lucerne) plus 4-5 kg dry fodder and 1 kg oil-cake or commercial cattle feed every day.  
2. Always mix 50–75 g mineral mixture and a pinch of common salt in the concentrate; lack of minerals is a common cause of weakness.  
3. Make sure they have clean water all day; a cow needs at least 40–60 litres daily for proper digestion and milk production.  
4. Deworm all cattle every 6 months with albendazole or fenbendazole (dose as per the vet) because internal parasites steal nutrients and cause weight loss.  
5. Check for external parasites like ticks; if present, spray the animal and shed with 1–2 % diazinon or cypermethrin solution.  
6. Provide shade and good ventilation; heat stress lowers feed intake and makes cows look dull.  
7. Examine the teeth of older animals—worn teeth reduce the ability to chew fodder; such cows need softer, chopped feed.  
8. If weakness comes suddenly, look for fever, diarrhoea, or reduced milk and call a veterinarian immediately for blood tests; diseases like theileriosis, trypanosomiasis or FMD need quick treatment.  
9. Vaccinate regularly (FMD every 6 months, HS once a year, BQ and Brucellosis as advised) to prevent disease-related weakness.  
10. Keep records of feed given, milk yield and body condition; this helps you and the vet spot problems early and adjust the ration or treatment.

Question: How do I control yellow pests in paddy fields?
answer:
1. First be sure the “yellow pest” is the yellow stem-borer: the adult is a small yellow moth and its creamy-yellow caterpillar bores inside the rice tiller, giving “dead-heart” (centre leaf dries) in early crop and “white-ear” (empty panicle) later.  
2. After harvest, plough or burn stubbles and destroy volunteer ratoons so the borer cannot survive in the field.  
3. Sow and transplant as early and as uniformly as possible with your neighbours; scattered late fields keep the insect alive for longer.  
4. Do not over-use urea; split the recommended nitrogen dose into 3–4 parts because very lush plants attract more borers.  
5. At 15–20 days after transplanting, place 4–5 pheromone traps per acre (10–12 per hectare) to monitor and mass-trap the male moths; replace lures every 20–25 days.  
6. Release one Trichogramma japonicum egg-parasitoid card per acre (2.5 cards/ha) at 30, 37 and 44 days after transplanting; pin the card under the leaf in the morning.  
7. Keep the field flooded (2–3 cm) and broadcast any granular insecticide only on standing water for good distribution.  
8. When 1–2% dead-heart tillers or 5 moths/trap/night are seen, apply cartap hydrochloride 4G at 10 kg/acre (25 kg/ha) or fipronil 0.3G at 12 kg/acre (30 kg/ha).  
9. For spray treatment, you may mix 60 ml chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC or 100 g flubendiamide 20 WG in 15 litres water and spray one tank per acre, keeping nozzle directed at the tiller bases.  
10. Rotate chemicals each season, avoid spraying after 5 pm when Trichogramma is active, and always use gloves and mask for your own safety.

Question: How do I prevent cotton bollworm?
answer:
1. Choose a Bt cotton hybrid that is still giving good field control in your area, sow on time (by mid-May in north India, by June in central and south zones) and avoid continuous cotton on the same land for more than two years.  
2. Keep the field clean of alternate host weeds (parthenium, tomato, chickpea residues) and plant 2–3 rows of marigold or pigeon-pea as a trap crop around the plot.  
3. Install 5 pheromone traps per hectare; if you catch more than 8 moths per trap per night, or if field scouting shows 5 small larvae per 20 plants, prepare to act.  
4. At egg stage, release the egg-parasitoid Trichogramma chilonis at 50,000 adults per hectare every 7–10 days, three times.  
5. Spray neem seed-kernel extract 5 % or neem oil 2 ml/L when eggs/early larvae appear; it repels and slows the pest without harming natural enemies.  
6. For heavier infestation, spray HaNPV (Helicoverpa NPV) 250 LE or 1.5 × 10¹² PIB per hectare in the late afternoon mixed with 0.1 % jaggery and 0.1 % sticker.  
7. If larvae exceed the economic threshold even after these steps, use one selective insecticide: emamectin benzoate 5 SG 220 g/ha, indoxacarb 14.5 SC 500 ml/ha, spinosad 45 SC 75 ml/ha, or chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC 150 ml/ha, ensuring good spray coverage.  
8. Always rotate insecticides from different groups and avoid more than two sprays of any single group in one season to delay resistance.  
9. Pick and bury damaged bolls, and after harvest plough under crop residue to kill pupae in the soil.  
10. Finally, keep field records of moth catches, sprays and costs; this will help you fine-tune the bollworm management plan each season.

Question: What is the best fertilizer when planting?
answer: There is no single “best” fertilizer for every field; the right one depends on your soil and the crop you are planting. First, if possible, do a simple soil test (many Krishi Vigyan Kendras and private labs offer this for a small fee) so you know how much nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) and potassium (K) are already present. For most cereals like wheat or maize, a balanced basal dose of about 60 kg N, 40 kg P₂O₅ and 20 kg K₂O per acre works well; this can be supplied with 130 kg urea, 100 kg DAP and 35 kg MOP, applied just before or at sowing and mixed into the topsoil. For pulses, reduce nitrogen (they fix their own) and give more phosphorus: about 20 kg N and 40 kg P₂O₅ per acre, often met with 90 kg SSP and 45 kg urea. Always add 1–2 t/acre of well-decomposed farmyard manure or compost; it improves soil structure and supplies micronutrients. If your soil-test report shows zinc or sulfur deficiency, mix 10 kg zinc sulfate or 20 kg gypsum per acre with the basal fertilizer. Place chemical fertilizers 5–7 cm away from the seed to avoid burning but close enough for young roots to reach. Finally, split-apply the remaining nitrogen (usually half) in two equal doses at 20–25 days and 40–45 days after sowing to reduce losses and boost yield.

Question: How much cow dung should be applied per hectare?
answer:
For ordinary field crops like wheat, paddy or maize, apply 8–10 tractor-trolley loads (about 10–12 tonnes) of well-rotted cow dung per hectare.  
If you are growing nutrient-hungry crops such as vegetables, sugarcane or banana, raise the dose to 20–25 t/ha.  
Always use dung that has been heaped under shade for at least 2–3 months so it is fully decomposed and free of weed seeds.  
Broadcast the manure uniformly over the plot and incorporate it 10–15 cm deep with a plough or rotavator 3–4 weeks before sowing or transplanting.  
On very sandy or degraded soils you can add 25 % more manure to improve organic carbon and water-holding capacity.  
If a recent soil test shows low nitrogen, mix 1 kg single super phosphate or 500 g rock phosphate with every quintal of dung to cut nitrogen loss and add extra P.  
Keep the dung slightly moist but not water-logged while it is decomposing to preserve nutrients.  
Remember that well-rotted cow dung supplies roughly 0.5 % N, 0.2 % P₂O₅ and 0.5 % K₂O, so chemical fertiliser may still be needed according to soil-test recommendations.  
Avoid applying fresh, un-decomposed dung—it ties up nitrogen, heats the soil and can spread pathogens.  
Finally, rotate the manure application area each season to build up soil health evenly across the farm.

Question: What are the common diseases that affect cattle?
answer:
1. Foot-and-Mouth Disease (FMD) is widespread; it causes fever, blisters in the mouth and on the feet, loss of appetite, and can kill young calves if not vaccinated against.

6. Lumpy Skin Disease shows firm skin nodules, fever and enlarged lymph nodes, spreading quickly through biting insects if animals are unvaccinated.  
7. Tick-borne illnesses such as Theileriosis, Babesiosis and Anaplasmosis give high fever, anemia and weakness; regular tick control and specific vaccines prevent heavy losses.  
8. Internal parasites (roundworms, liver flukes) and chronic diseases like Bovine Tuberculosis or Johne’s Disease silently reduce growth and milk, so follow a de-worming schedule and cull persistent reactors.  
9. Good disease control depends on timely vaccination (FMD, HS, BQ, LSD, Brucella, Theileria), strict hygiene during milking, regular de-worming and tick dipping, and quick isolation of any sick animal.  
10. Keep herd records and call a veterinarian at the first sign of fever, swellings, abortions or drop in milk to prevent these common diseases from spreading through your cattle.

Question: What causes dandruff in onions?

“Dandruff” on onion bulbs is the black, dust-like coating that appears between the dry outer scales.

3. Temperatures above about 30 °C and high humidity in the field or store encourage the mould.  
4. Bulbs that are harvested too early, roughly handled, or bruised during transport are most at risk.  
5. Cure onions 7–10 days in the field or on raised racks until the necks are tight and outer skins turn paper-dry.  
6. Handle bulbs gently and sort out any damaged or diseased ones before storage.  
7. Store only well-cured bulbs in a cool (below 25 °C), dry, well-ventilated place or in mesh bags; keep relative humidity below 70 %.  
8. A preventive spray of a broad-spectrum fungicide such as mancozeb 10–15 days before harvest can cut down field infection.  
9. By proper curing, careful handling, clean sorting and dry, cool storage, you can largely avoid “dandruff” and keep onions market-ready for longer.

Question: What are the main symptoms of common parasitic diseases found in animals?
answer:
Look for loss of body weight or stunted growth even though the animal is eating well; worms and other internal parasites steal the feed’s nutrients.  
Frequent soft or watery dung, sometimes with mucus or blood, points to stomach- or intestinal-worms or coccidia.  
A pale colour of eye membranes, gums or inside the ears (instead of healthy pink) shows anaemia caused by blood-sucking parasites such as Haemonchus worms, ticks or lice.  
Swelling under the lower jaw (“bottle-jaw”) in goats and sheep is a classic sign of severe worm infection or liver flukes.  
Coughing, rapid breathing or nasal discharge may appear when lungworms are present.  
A rough, dull hair-coat, itching, excessive scratching or bald patches indicate external parasites like mites, lice or fleas.  
Reduced milk yield, fewer eggs, poor fertility and general weakness are common in all heavy parasite loads.  
In poultry, ruffled feathers, drooping wings and blood-streaked droppings often signal coccidiosis or roundworms.  
If two or more of these signs are seen, collect dung samples for a worm-egg count or consult the vet to choose the right de-wormer or spray.

5. Close the room for 48 hours, then open and ventilate well for another day to remove chemical fumes—this “blanket disinfection” kills most competitor fungi, bacteria and insects.  
6. Install two or three-tier wooden or metal racks 60 cm wide, leaving 45 cm between tiers, so compost trays/beds sit off the floor and air can circulate.  
7. Keep a footbath of 2 % formalin at the entrance and insist that anyone entering dips footwear and washes hands with soap to avoid bringing in disease spores.  
8. Provide a small water sprayer or fine-rose watering can inside the room; never splash water—only mist—to maintain high humidity without wetting the compost surface.  
9. Place a thermometer and a cheap hygrometer inside; if temperature rises above 25 °C, open vents or run a small exhaust fan, and if humidity falls below 80 %, lightly mist walls and floor.  
10. After the room is fully prepared and aired, bring in well-pasteurized, cooled compost, spawn it on racks at 22–24 °C, cover with casing soil after 16–18 days, then drop temperature to 16–18 °C to start button formation.

Question: When can you cultivate paddy in Bihar?

In Bihar you can grow rice in three distinct seasons, choosing the one that fits your water supply and labour best.  
1. Main (Kharif or “Aghani”) crop: raise the nursery between 25 May and 20 June, transplant 20 June-20 July after the first steady monsoon showers, and harvest October-December.  
2. Early (Aus or “Satha”) crop: dry-seed or drum-seed directly in the field during February-March, transplant (if you use a nursery) in April, and harvest August-September; this needs assured irrigation because monsoon has not started yet.  
3. Winter/boro crop: sow the nursery in October-November on raised beds, transplant in December-January under assured irrigation or flood-recession moisture, and harvest April-May.  

Most smallholders in Bihar select the Kharif window because rainfall is reliable then; choose boro or aus only if you have tube-well or canal water. Always keep 25-30-day-old seedlings for transplanting, puddle the field well, and try to finish transplanting before 20 July for Kharif or before mid-January for boro to get the highest yield and avoid late pest and flood damage.

Question: When can you cultivate onions?
answer:
Onion can be grown almost year-round in India, but you will get best yields if you match the crop to the right season and temperature.  

1. Kharif crop: sow seed in nursery beds during June–July, transplant 6-week-old seedlings in August–September, and harvest bulbs in December–January.  
2. Late-kharif/early-rabi crop: sow in August–September, transplant in October–November, harvest in February–March.  
3. Rabi (main) crop: sow in October–November, transplant in December–January, harvest in April–May; this crop stores the longest.  
4. Summer crop (mainly in irrigated areas): direct seed or transplant in January–February and harvest in May–June, but protect young plants from hot winds.  

Choose short-day varieties (e.g., Agrifound Light Red, Arka Kalyan) for kharif and long-day or intermediate types (e.g., N-53, Bhima Super) for rabi. Germination and early growth need 13–24 °C; bulb formation is fastest at 25–30 °C, and the crop dislikes waterlogging, especially at maturity.

Question: How can I plant mushrooms?
answer:
1. Start with an easy, fast-growing variety such as oyster mushroom (Pleurotus spp.) or paddy-straw mushroom, and buy fresh spawn (seed) from a reliable government lab or Krishi Vigyan Kendra.  
2. Chop clean paddy or wheat straw into 3-5 cm pieces, soak it in water for 6–8 hours, then pasteurise by boiling/steaming for 1 hour; drain until only a few drops of water come out when you squeeze a handful.  
3. When the straw cools to room temperature, fill it loosely into perforated polythene bags (or stack it in a column), sprinkling spawn in 3–4 layers at about 5 % of straw weight.  
4. Tie the bags and hang or rack them in a dark, well-ventilated room kept at 24–28 °C and 80–90 % humidity; mist the walls/floor twice daily but keep the bags just moist, not wet.  
5. In 15–20 days the white mycelium will fully cover the straw; then cut open or peel off the plastic so the “blocks” are exposed to indirect light and fresh air.  
6. Maintain high humidity by misting 2–3 times daily; small “pins” will appear within a week and grow into harvestable mushrooms in another 3–4 days.  
7. Harvest by gently twisting when the caps are still curled downward and before they flatten; pick every 2–3 days for 3–4 flushes.  
8. Expect roughly 1 kg of fresh mushrooms for every 1 kg of dry straw if hygiene and moisture are good.  
9. After the final flush, use the spent straw as compost or cattle feed, and clean the room with lime or bleach solution to reduce disease for the next cycle.  
10. Work cleanly, keep temperatures and humidity as noted, and you can repeat the process every 45–60 days for a steady income.

Question: What diseases are caused by mushrooms?
answer:
1. The white or brown “caps” we call mushrooms are only the fruiting bodies of certain fungi; by themselves they usually do not make crops sick.  
2. A few fungi that form mushroom-like bodies do attack plants—for example Armillaria causes root-rot in many fruit and forest trees, and Ganoderma bracket fungi cause red- or white-rot and wilting in coconut, arecanut, banana and oil-palm.  
3. Shelf or bracket fungi such as Phellinus and Fomes grow on trunks and produce “heart-rot,” hollowing out and eventually killing timber trees.  
4. Relatives of mushrooms also give us maize smut (Ustilago), wheat rust (Puccinia) and rice sheath blight (Rhizoctonia), although these particular fungi do not form large caps that we notice in the field.  
5. For people, the main danger is eating poisonous wild mushrooms like Amanita, Galerina or some Lepiota species, which can cause severe food-poisoning, liver or kidney failure and even death.  
6. Workers who breathe heavy clouds of mushroom spores daily in closed sheds can develop an allergic lung problem called “mushroom worker’s lung.”  
7. Cultivated mushrooms sold as button, oyster or milky mushroom are safe and nutritious when grown on clean substrate and harvested young, so the key is to avoid unknown wild mushrooms and manage tree-rotting fungi promptly.

Question: What types of mushrooms are there?
answer:
Mushrooms can be broadly grouped into edible/cultivable types, medicinal/specialty types, and poisonous wild types.  
For regular commercial cultivation in India, the main edible species are: White Button Mushroom (Agaricus bisporus), Oyster Mushroom (Pleurotus spp.), Paddy-Straw Mushroom (Volvariella volvacea) and Milky Mushroom (Calocybe indica).  
White Button grows in cooler weather (15-22 °C) and is the variety most commonly sold in urban markets.  
Oyster mushrooms tolerate a wider temperature range (18-30 °C), grow on many crop residues and give a quick, reliable harvest.  
Paddy-Straw mushrooms like very warm, humid conditions (28-35 °C) and are popular in eastern and southern India.  
Milky mushrooms need 25-35 °C, perform well in summer and the rainy season, and keep their white colour for several days after harvest.  
Specialty or medicinal mushrooms such as Shiitake (Lentinula edodes), Reishi/Lingzhi (Ganoderma lucidum) and Enoki require more controlled environments but fetch higher prices.  
Never collect or eat wild mushrooms unless they are positively identified by an expert, because many poisonous species (e.g., certain Amanitas) closely resemble edible ones.
